attachments.fallback: [January 18th, 2017 4:17 AM] sumitks: Hi I just wanted to know if there is any difference in size of traditional database vs a block chain database for same number of transactions??
attachments.text: Hi I just wanted to know if there is any difference in size of traditional database vs a block chain database for same number of transactions??

text: <@U2BF87970> - the state "database"  - which is snapshot of the latest value(s) for the various keys - is going to basically be the same size as a normal database for the same number of records (key/value pairs).   but along with that we also have the "ledger" (the closest analog in the database world would be the transaction log) which will contain the entire history of updates for every key.   This will definitely be larger in size than a database log although by how much will depend on the number of endorsements required and a few other factors.   I'll let the ledger folks add / correct me  :wink:

I am looking for a way to use blockchain to record the accesses (both read and write) to an EXTERNAL data source, in my case a DB2 database.  Can some give me some suggestions on how this should be done? All of the examples that I've seen so far store ALL state data inside of the blockchain.
can the config in core.yaml `ledger.state.stateDatabase` point to my own database?  if I were going to point `ledger.state.stateDatabase` to my own database, what would I need to do?

<@U3U0MV3PZ>  Are you asking if DB2 can be used as *the* data store for the state database, or are you asking if the state database can be replicated to DB2 in *addition* to the state database.  I suspect the former, but please clarify.  And indeed if it is the former, in v1.0 the design is for the state database to be pluggable.  In fact, an implementation has already been coded to use CouchDB as an alternative to the v1.0 default of goLevelDB.  
You may want to re-ask your question (please try to clarify to address my initial question here if what I asked makes any sense) in <#C2GFRAE7P|fabric-ledger-dev> as I think you're more likely to get the attention of the developers who created the CouchDB implementation.   (Not sure if the implementation of CouchDB is complete or still in the works, but I think the developers in <#C2GFRAE7P|fabric-ledger-dev> will know).

<@U0YJUECE8> what I am looking for is using blockchain to "control and record" accesses to off-chain data, e.g.

Application would query chaincode to access off-chain data, 
The chaincode would get the "access policies" stored on chain and verify permissions
Retrieve off-chain data
Record the access to the offchain data
Return the off-chain data to application

<@U3U0MV3PZ> hmm interesting use case, do you have to have the chaincode access the off-chain data directly or could you have a front-end app accessing the chaincode for access policies, getting a authn/authz decision that way, and then the front-end app could access the off-chain data?   Also, is the off-chain data a read-only reference or would it be updated?  There is a lot to consider.   The fact that chaincode needs to be deterministic is a key consideration.  And if you have multiple organizations that don't necessarily trust each other (which is an essential characteristic of blockchain to begin with), is this off-chain data available to all parties?  

This is an area of interest to me, the integration of blockchain apps with other "Systems of Record", but I'm afraid I don't have any good answers for you, at this point, just more questions- trying to give you some "food for thought" and maybe stir some minds greater than mine to enter the discussion.  :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U0YJUECE8> having the front-end app accessing the chaincode to control and access policies is insecure since if the application is hacked, there would be no control and record at all. and this would happen even if there is one app hacked.
the availability of the off-chain data is based on "contracts" between the parties
<@U3U0MV3PZ> ok, well, like I said, I'm afraid I'm not equipped at this time to give you a good answer, hopefully others might weigh in to help.  Good luck!
Hi, In car lease demo, is the validation of transaction being contribute by all,i.e as all are involved under single transaction or not?

Check out the latest ledger playback w/couchdb! <https://youtu.be/XoW9gjAH93k> … if you haven’t subscribed to the youtube channel do so for auto notifications at <https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCFdgCWH_1vCndMPVqQlwZw>
